473.67.text:

Well, I was born in Marion,
North Dakota, in a small town

480.30.text:
on a livestock and grain farm
operation without electricity,

487.27.text:
like so many rural kids

491.20.text:

495.53.text:
Those were a very tough
first few years

498.67.text:
living out all by myself,
out on that farm.

503.87.text: so going to church on Sunday

506.03.text:
and any social event
where I could

509.03.text:

was the highlight of my life.

513.00.text:

very strong

516.57.text:
because I was always outside
hunting, in my own mind,

521.00.text:
or playing war games,

524.20.text:

530.70.text:
and I can remember filling up

535.63.text:

538.93.text:
with drawings of heroic cowboys

543.30.text:

550.90.text:

554.60.text: and I wanted to go to college

because I wanted

especially the Fritz Scholder
that's on the wall.

1418.93.text:
Fritz Scholder painted a couple
images right on the wall,

1422.73.text:
and it'd be tough I think
to sell that place

1426.40.text:
because you maybe have to
go in there and cut that out.

1430.80.text:
I have the first painting
that he did

1434.87.text: of a bucking horse and rider,

1442.53.text:
The horse doesn't have legs
on it, so he's cut that off.

1447.33.text: I want to hang on to that

1449.57.text:
'cause I can see where it began
and where it's gone.

1453.10.text:
(man)
Every year, he always has work

1457.73.text: Two years ago for the show,

1459.97.text: he did a fine piece of work

1462.60.text:
that he and Marjorie Schlossman
worked on it together;

1466.03.text: as far as I know, the first time

1468.87.text:
he's ever done a painting
with another artist.

1471.63.text:
Marjorie first painted
on the painting in Fargo,

1476.07.text:
and then he painted on it
after that,

1479.27.text: and it turned out quite well.

1481.67.text:
(Darryl Dorgan)
I always wanted a Walter Piehl.

1484.43.text:
He painted this;
it's called "Orange Crush."

1487.33.text: It's a beautiful piece of work.

1489.20.text:
It has a lot
of different color in it,

1491.97.text: and I like a lot of color,

1494.17.text:
but his color really adds to
the vibrancy

1496.83.text:
of what he's doing, it adds
to the motion.

1501.83.text:
what you see is a young kid
who's riding saddle bronc,

1505.13.text:
and it is technically correct
from the word go.

1507.87.text:
He's marking him when he's
coming out of the shoots.

1510.27.text:
Notice his toes
are pointed out,
his boots are pointed out,

1512.90.text:
his spurs are up
on the horse's shoulders,

1514.83.text:
his arm is thrown back,
and he's leaning way back,

1517.63.text:
and you can see
the horse's ears are back,

1520.17.text: and you can see the motion.

1521.90.text:
You can feel the ground moving
in that arena,

1524.47.text:
and you can feel
what this kid is going through,

1527.23.text:
and you can feel
what this horse is doing.

1529.47.text:
It's just a great piece, and
every time you look at that

(Laurel) Early on,
I looked very carefully

1538.80.text: at the work of Walter Piehl,

1542.17.text: and I decided this was an artist

1544.73.text: I would place my money on,

1546.90.text: and I made a very good bet.

1549.53.text:
He is one of North Dakota's
most important artists now,

1554.43.text:
and he will be
that historically as well.

these are all potential names.

where would I come up with

That's a good,
that's a good title.

a great name for a buckin'

the North Dakota
